G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, G.L. c. 208, § 28 provides that child custody and parenting time orders may be modified upon a showing that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and that such a modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Bennett, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 208, § 28A, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order issued on April 15, 2019, by the Bristol County Probate and Family Court.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, courts must consider a variety of factors, including the child’s age, educational needs, emotional well-being, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed in a custody determination. In applying that standard, the court relies on findings about the child’s weekday/school situation, medical and educational needs, emotional and relational ties with each parent, and each parent’s work schedule and ability to meet those needs. While it does not list age, education, and emotional well-being as a formal multi-factor test, its reasoning reflects consideration of a variety of such factors in determining best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … The judge awarded legal custody of Kali to the mother… based, in turn, on a number of findings, including… that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues… that the father works long hours… that the mother has more flexible hours and is able to spend more time with Kali during the weekdays… [and] that it is important that Kali be able to spend as much time as possible with her father… to continue to foster their close and positive relationship.”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, courts must consider a variety of factors, including the child’s age, educational needs, emotional well-being, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The court expressly defines the best-interests standard as grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child and then applies it by evaluating multiple concrete factors: the child’s special educational needs and current school supports, his social and emotional development, the impact of moving homes and schools, and the effect of reduced parenting time with the father. This reasoning aligns with the proposition that courts must consider a variety of factors, including age-related developmental and educational needs, emotional well-being, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs when determining the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests, that potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household weighed against increased physical custody by the mother, and that any financial or other advantage of the move to the mother was unclear.”}

Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 926.raw_text: Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 926 (1998)
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 926.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a modified parenting schedule that responds to the child’s changing needs as they grow is essential for their well-being.
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 926.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on reaffirming that custody determinations rest in the trial judge’s discretion and are governed by the child’s best interests, particularly the child’s happiness and welfare. It does not discuss modified parenting schedules over time, changing developmental needs as children grow, or the importance of periodically adjusting parenting plans. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about evolving parenting schedules being essential for a child’s well-being.
Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924, 926.relevant_excerpt: “In any event, in Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997), decided after judgment entered in this case, the Supreme Judicial Court reaffirmed the principle set forth in the Vilakazi decision that the custody of a child is to be determined by the ‘happiness and welfare of the child’ (371 Mass. at 409) and rests within the discretion of the trial judge. 426 Mass. at 251.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long recognized that a modified parenting schedule that responds to the child’s changing needs as they grow is essential for their well-being.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether separating identical twin siblings in a custody modification serves their best interests, emphasizing the presumption that siblings should be kept together. It does not discuss or endorse a general principle that parenting schedules should be modified over time to respond to children’s changing developmental needs. The reasoning is about best interests, material change in circumstances, and sibling unity—not about an evolving or staged parenting plan as essential to well-being.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. … The list of factors within the judge’s purview in child custody matters includes a presumption generally favoring the placement of siblings under one roof.”
